results.title: Deirdre Jack: Swifts Creek Artist
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Local painter, Deirdre Jack, is passionate about her local environment. The rolling hills and golden fields that surround her Swifts Creek bush studio inevitably make their way into her vibrant oil paintings and pastel sketches. Fruit, however, is the main subject of her exhibition at the Great Alpine Gallery, a small exhibition space that sits in the heart of Swifts Creek and run voluntarily by a group of fellow artists. The gallery has been a vital place for local artists since 1989 despite the challenges of running an art space in a small rural town.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, David Withers and ACMI

results.title: The Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The small country town of Swifts Creek has had a bush nursing service since 1918 when staff were originally travelling on horseback. These days the bush nurse Sue Carroll visits patients in a 4WD and understands the importance of providing medical care to locals that are often isolated and unable to travel to the Omeo Hospital. Whether it’s farmers in need of wound management, children with the measles or victims of car accidents, Carroll is usually the first person on the scene. Part nurse, part social worker, all legend; Carroll and the staff at the Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre provide a vital 24/7 service to not only the local community but the wider surrounding regional area.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from East Gippsland
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The towns of Swifts Creek, Omeo, Lakes Entrance, Orbost, Marlo and Cape Conran are quite distinct from each other but all make up the region of East Gippsland, which lies in the south-east of Victoria. In ‘ACMI in the regions: stories from East Gippsland’, locals from each town are interviewed about their lives, their community and what makes living in these towns so special.

results.title: Welcome to Cape Conran
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Have you ever wondered what it’s like to live and work in a National Park? Cape Conran Coastal Park consists of 11,700 hectares of pristine coastal wilderness. Meet Carla and Josh Puglisi who manage the park as well as Mike Irvine; the park ranger, as they talk about the importance of protecting the coastal environment, the rich indigenous history of the area as well as what it’s like living within and raising families in such a beautiful place.

results.title: Paddle Steamer Curlip
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Join a group of passionate volunteers as they describe the trials, tribulations and joys of building and running a paddle steamer. From the initial planning in 2002, a group of Orbost locals built the PS Curlip II as part of a community project. After 16,000 hours of voluntary labour the paddle steamer was launched and continues in 2013 to transport tourists in and around the various waterways of East Gippsland. Members of the PS Curlip Committee talk about the history, their involvement and the future of the much-loved paddle steamer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Montgomery, Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.

results.title: Fishing on the Diamantina
results.creator_credit: Wayne Gwynne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Wayne Gwynne joined the Navy in 1960 when he was 17. Spending 5 years at sea, during peacetime, Gwynne got to see things that no one has seen before. While he still can’t talk about those things, he loved his time at sea, especially on his favourite ship, the ‘Diamantina’.

results.title: The Battle of Coral
results.creator_credit: Tony Stewart, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Instinct kicked in when Private Tony Stewart and his fellow soldiers were engaged in the Battle for Coral, in Vietnam, 1968. It was the most horrific battle he would take part in but this is what Stewart was trained for and he know he had his mates there to look after him.

results.title: 22R&SU
results.creator_credit: Thomas Lawless, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Every young man wanted to be in the airforce but it was very selective. With technical training, Thomas Lawless found that he was most needed repairing and servicing aircraft during World War II. While being thrown into some intense situations, Lawless and his team formed strong bonds that could never be broken.

results.title: A Look from their side
results.creator_credit: Robert Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Reflecting on his service in Borneo during World War II, Robert Cole was impressed by the kindness and warmth of the local people, despite being forced to live through war and poverty. In doing so, they taught Cole about gratitude.
